bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Kenneth F. Maxcy, September 18, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses theories and scientific studies on immunization from malaria by quinine and on the blood supplies of particular types of mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Kenneth F. Maxcy, September 18, 1923
div1.opener:
Malaria
Maxcy
/LC
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N. C.,
Sept. 18, 1923.
Dear Doctor Maxcy:
div1.p: This is just a note in more or less answer to your letter.

1/ I don't recollect the work you alluded to by Stott on re-
lapses in malaria. In the early part of 1916, I read one--I think
two--articles by Stott and someone else, in a British or Indian medi-
cal journal, giving some rather elaborate observations on the use of
quinine to immunize against malaria (the so-called “quinine prophylaxis
by the Italian method”). He used alternate units as controls The result was decidedly against its value
and the implied deduction was that almost the only--or only--value it
had was not to the men taking it--i. e. that it did not immunize them,
but by preventing parasites in their cutaneous circulation anopheles
cannot be infected from them and thus it protects the others who did not
take it: insshort acting as long as it was taken like Koch's method--
(the sterilization of carriers).

This theory is in direct contradiction to the fining of many
carriers among those taking quinine this way: by Malcolm Watson in the
Malay States: Ozard and others in Venezuela and in short I think of all
who have examined them.

In this connection, when I was writing my little brocheur on im-
munization from malaria by quinine, I had some correspondance with
Celli and, at my instance, he agreed to have a blood index taken of a
large number who had received his treatment and, if possible, compare
it with the men under the same conditions who had not. I thought there
was no place so good as Italy for investigating the effect of this immu-
immu- 2
nizing treatment on the existence of carriers (with parasites in the cu-
taneous circulation infective to Anopheles) as Italy. Unfortunately
he died not long afterwards and I have seen no report of any such
work.

Mayne (who was “Mitzmain” then) told me that he knew Stott per-
sonally and by reputation and that he was not regarded as very reliable.

Sellera is a very much smaller man than Celli and has recently
done some work at Fiumicine in Italy and at ---- in Spain. His obser-
vations on relapse are, I think, of small value.

Komp advised me recently that some observations have been made
tending to show that punctipennis habitually gets its blood supply
from other than human sources. LePrince: Griffitts and myself had the
same idea in 1914-15, led thereto by finding them so much more fre-
quently in stables: chicken houses: pig pens etc. than in residences.
We found, however, so much “porch biting” of men by punctipennis in /15
and /16 that we carried it no further. Field observations (at Chester
S. C.: Bridgewater, N. C. and some places in Virginia) show that puncti-
pennis--Headlee to the contrary:--do produce epidemics of malaria,
though I still think are less efficient than A. quad. or A. crucians.
The data Komp gives (the determination of the source of the blood found
in the insects) offers, however, a good index as to the proportion of
human and other blood they actually have taken.
